text: MOSP 2011 Blue Joshua Nichols-Barrer Completeness 1. Determine all functions f : R → R such that for each x, y ∈ R, f (x + y) = f (x) + f (y) and f (xy) = f (x)f (y). 2. Prove Kronecker’s Theorem: Let α be an irrational real. Prove that for any interval I ⊆ [0, 1), there is a positive integer n with {nα} ∈ I. 3. Let x1, x2, . . . , xk be real numbers and let ϵ > 0. Prove that there exists a positive integer n such that {nxi} < ϵ for all i. 4. Consider the sequence deﬁned by a1 = 1, and an+1 = an + 1/a 2 n for n ≥ 1. (a) Is the sequence (an) ∞ n=1 bounded? (b) Prove that a9000 > 30. 5. Let x1, x2, . . . , x2n+1 be real numbers with the property that for any 1 ≤ i ≤ 2n + 1 one can make two groups of n numbers from the xj, j ̸= i, in such a way that the two groups each have the same sum. Prove that all the numbers must be equal. 6. Let k, m, n be positive integers with k, m < n and (k, m) = 1. Suppose that a1, a2, . . . , an are real numbers such that for any indices 1 ≤ i1 < i2 < · · · < ik ≤ n there exist indices 1 ≤ j1 < j2 < · · · < jm ≤ n with ai1 + ai2 + · · · + aik k = aj1 + aj2 + · · · + ajm m . Prove that a1 = a2 = · · · = an. 7. Let {xn}∞ n=0 be a sequence of real numbers such that x0 = 1 and xi+1 ≤ xi for i = 0, 1, 2, . . .. (a) Prove that for every such sequence there is an n > 0 such that x2 0 x1 + x2 1 x2 + · · · + x2 n−1 xn ≥ 3.999. (b) Find such a sequence in which x2 0 x1 + x2 1 x2 + · · · + x2 n−1 xn < 4 for all n. 1 MOSP 2011 Blue Joshua Nichols-Barrer 8. Deﬁne the sequence of rational numbers {tn} as follows. Let c1 be a given positive integer, and let t1 = 1 c 1. For a positive integer n, let tn+1 = tn if tn = 1. Otherwise, let cn+1 be the least integer such that cn+1 > cn and tn+1 = tn + 1 cn+1 ≤ 1. Show that the sequence{tn} is eventually constant. 9. Two sequences of positive real numbers (xn) ∞ n=0 and (yn) ∞ n=1, satisfy xn+2 = xn + x2 n+1 and yn+2 = y2 n + yn+1. for all n > 0. Prove that if x1, x2, y1, y2 > 1, then xk > yk for some k. 10. Let {an}∞ n=1 and {bn}∞ n=1 be two sequences of real numbers such that an+1 = 2bn − an and bn+1 = 2an − bn for every positive integer n. Prove that if an > 0 for all n, then a1 = b1. 11. Find all functions f : R>0 → R>0 such that for all x, y ∈ R >0, f (x) 2 ≥ f (x + y)(f (x) + y). 12. An inﬁnite set S of points on the plane has the property that no 1 × 1 square of the plane contains inﬁnitely many points from S. Prove that there exist two points A and B from S such that min{XA, XB} ≥ 0.999AB for any other point X in S. 13. Determine whether there exists a polynomial P (x) with real coeﬃcients, not identically zero, for which we can ﬁnd a function f : R → R that satisﬁes the relation f (x) − x3 3 · f (3x − 3 3 + x ) = P ( 3x + 3 3 − x ) for all irrational numbers x. 14. Find all strictly increasing f : R → R such that f (x) + f −1(x) = 2x. 15. Find all f : R → R for which f (xy) = f (x)f (y) − f (x + y) + 1. 16. The sequence f1, f2, . . . , fn, . . . is deﬁned for x > 0 recursively by f1(x) = x, fn+1(x) = fn(x) ( fn(x) + 1 n ) . Prove that there exists one and only one positive number a such that 0 < fn(a) < fn+1(a) < 1 for all integers n ≥ 1. 2 MOSP 2011 Blue Joshua Nichols-Barrer 17. Let S be the set of all polygonal areas in the plane. Prove that there is a function f : S → (0, 1) which satisﬁes f (S1 ∪ S2) = f (S1) + f (S2) for any S1, S2 ∈ S which have common points only on their borders. 18. The inﬁnite sequence of 2’s and 3’s 2, 3, 3, 2, 3, 3, 3, 2, 3, 3, 3, 2, 3, 3, 2, 3, 3, 3, 2, 3, 3, 3, 2, 3, 3, 3, 2, 3, 3, 2, 3, 3, 3, 2, . . . has the property that, if one forms a second sequence that records the number of 3’s between successive 2’s, the result is identical to the given sequence. Show that there exists a real number r such that, for any n, the n th term of the sequence if 2 if and only if n = 1 + ⌊rm⌋ for some nonnegative integer m. 3
